This legislation is a travesty.  You are actively ignoring best-practice guidelines for safe streets, and are putting the convenience of saving a few seconds for drivers (including, conveniently, the Minister of Transportation who refuses to take public transportation to work) ahead of the safety of all road users and environmental concerns.
More people will be injured on the roads because of this policy.  Full stop.  A letter from physicians and researchers at the University of Toronto:  https://healthydebate.ca/2024/10/topic/legislation-road-design-safety-t…
Like many policies of the current government, it seems that Doug Ford is more interested in pretending that he is, in fact, mayor of Toronto than of dealing with major issues that fall under the provincial banner, like healthcare and education.
This addendum to the legislation also ignores the many actual causes of gridlock, including an unregulated ride-sharing industry, a refusal to toll public highways (and the unfortunate decision to sell highway 407 by the previous Conservative government), construction blocking active lanes, and near-constant on-street parking, and a lack of reliable and consistent public transit options in certain areas.

109691.comment:
It’s hard to imagine a bigger waste of provincial resources than this proposal. If the city consults with the people who live and work in that community and they agree that there should be a bike lane, why would the province ever need to step in? To defend whose interests? People who have driven in from other municipalities?
Not only is it ridiculous from a political-economic standpoint, but the proposal likely wouldn’t even achieve its goal. Study after study shows that adding more lanes for cars does not actually reduce congestion. Construction makes congestion worse; construction of the kind required to remove (popular and well used) bike lanes.
Bike lanes make drivers and cyclists safer, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and encourage a healthy lifestyle. Allowing the province to veto—or, even more absurdly, force the removal of—a bike lane is simply a way for the government to drum up support among its car-reliant base at the expense of the rights and desires of those living and working along these bike routes.
